title: Backend: Rename Ci::Minutes::Limit to CI::Minutes::Quota
description:
## Proposal

To clarify the code base and make it consistent with the UI and documentation rename `CI::Minutes::Limit` to `CI::Minutes::Quota` since quota is widely used in the front end.

## Why?

1. Make things consistent
1. `Quota` is widely used in the industry ([AWS](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws_service_limits.html), [Google Compute](https://cloud.google.com/storage/quotas))
    - tl;dr - Quotas can be adjusted up and limits are hard edges


<details><summary>Original issue description</summary>

In the backend code, we renamed what was `Quota` to `Usage` and `Limit`. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345577

In [the MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/83331) that changed quota to usage all of the reviewing backend engineers agreed that the concept of `usage` and `limit` is clearer than `quota` and we wanted to change the documentation and the UI so that the word `quota` is eliminated.

@drew said:

> To me, `usage` and `limit` are generally simpler terms, further clarified by a more obvious difference between them.

@fabiopitino said:

> Can we open an issue to just use `CI minutes limit` in docs and UI?

See the conversation: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/83331#note_935250905

</details>

title: Add index on vulnerability_feedback (finding_uuid)
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

The following discussion from !82143 should be addressed:

- [ ] @dfrazao-gitlab started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/82143#note_906268347):  (+4 comments)

    > query: `load_feedback`
    > 
    > I can see two red flags in this query/query+plan.
    > We are using a sequential scan and the `uuid` data type is different.
    > `vulnerability_occurrences` uses varchar
    > `vulnerability_feedback` uses uuid.

## Relevant links

- [Originating MR](#82143)

## Non-functional requirements

- [ ] Performance: Show query timing

## Implementation plan

- [ ] ~database Add index to vulnerability_feedback.finding_uuid

## Verification steps

1. Run the following query plan:

```
SELECT
    *
FROM
    vulnerability_feedback
WHERE
    finding_uuid = (
        SELECT
            finding_uuid
        FROM
            vulnerability_feedback
        LIMIT 1)
```

2. There should be an index call in the plan

[Current plan with no index](https://console.postgres.ai/gitlab/gitlab-production-tunnel-pg12/sessions/9977/commands/35279)

title: Background Migrations - Header Margin Followup
description:
## What/Why

Based on @nickbrandt suggestion here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/85639#note_935566166

We have some rogue margin hanging on the mobile view of `admin/background_migrations`:disappointed: 

![Screen_Shot_2022-05-05_at_11.04.09_AM](/uploads/6bbda85dda3dda3dfac13b45bdcaef3c/Screen_Shot_2022-05-04_at_5.54.41_PM.png)

## Thoughts

We should actually move the margin right on the title element over to margin-left on the Listbox element since it is conditionally there. This way we never have rogue margin.

However we only want the margin on `> sm` screens.  So we first need to add the class to GitLab UI

## Proposal

1. Add `.gl-sm-ml-7` to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui
2. Remove the `.gl-mr-7` introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/85639
3. Add `.gl-sm-ml-7` and `.gl-ml-0` to the conditional listbox element `js-database-listbox` introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/85639

_note: All class changes are to be done in this file: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/admin/background_migrations/index.html.haml_

title: Geo: JobArtifacts can't be verified on primary (and synced on secondary) when `sync_object_storage` is set to true
description:
If the file is stored in Object Storage and the `sync_object_storage` option is enabled, the file is not going to be verified. It's OK because it's not implemented yet and that is specified in https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/datatypes.html but the state records for those blobs should not be event created. This is how it's supposed to work for now until we don't support remotely stored blob verification. I currently see this problem for JobArtifacts, I didn't check other types.

## The Problem

Blobs are verified on primary again and again. The verification retry count value is very large.

## Expected behavior

Blobs that should not be verified should not be counted as `verifiables`, as we currently don't verify OS stored blobs. The state records shouldn't be even created.

epic.title: Geo: GA support for object storage replication

title: Geo: Blobs can't be verified when `sync_object_storage` is set to true
description:
Although the feature is in beta, of course, it should be fixed.

Details:
[ee/app/models/concerns/geo/blob_replicator_strategy.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a6bab105ff8b45d6be091cdc78f7016908489882/ee/app/models/concerns/geo/blob_replicator_strategy.rb)
```ruby
def checksummable?
  carrierwave_uploader.file_storage? && file_exists?
end
```

probably should be `(carrierwave_uploader.file_storage? || ::Gitlab::Geo.current_node.sync_object_storage?) && file_exists?`.

and the following line in the same file is not going to work for Object storage of course:
```ruby
model.sha256_hexdigest(blob_path)
```

title: Trivy Secret Detection Enabled By Default Since v0.27.0
description:
Trivy v0.27.0 added secret detection enabled by default. This can be extremely slow for larger images, and is causing scan timeouts / failures.

Since GitLab has another scanner for secret detection, should Trivy be doing secret detection as well? The below flag can be used to only scan for vulnerabilities. Can this either be exposed, or can the default be to just scan for vulnerabilities?

```
--security-checks value          comma-separated list of what security issues to detect (vuln,config,secret) (default: "vuln,secret") [$TRIVY_SECURITY_CHECKS]
```

We are temporarily working around this issue by pinning to a version that contains Trivy v0.26.0.

```
container_scanning:
  # Image tag 4.6.14 contains Trivy 0.26.0, avoiding timeout bug in Trivy 0.27.0.
  image: registry.gitlab.com/security-products/container-scanning:4.6.14
```

### Implementation plan

- [x] Use `--security-checks` to disable secret scanning in Trivy 0.27.0+

title: Enqueuer worker: scope the lease key with the repository id
description:
## :fire: Problem

The Enqueuer worker use an exclusive lease key to make sure that no two executions handle the same image repository.

The problem is that the lease key is currently a [fixed one](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a68471ff5daa4341d0c0ca32413a3bc2032c2bd5/app/workers/container_registry/migration/enqueuer_worker.rb#L165).

We're [observing](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/2c5b3510-cc69-11ec-afaf-2bca15dfbf33) a pretty high amount of `lease key taken` messages: 170K+ messages in the last 24 hours. That's 2.5 times the amount of successful executions that start migrations.

In addition to that, the exclusive lease key can be left behind during shutdowns/restarts.

Using a fixed key, these conditions will pause the migration for 30 minutes (the lease key duration).

The core issue is that migration on repo A has nothing to do with the migration on repo B. If there is an issue with the lease key while processing repo A, we shouldn't impact repo B execution.

## :fire_engine: Solution

* Scope the lease key with the repo id so that we still guarantee that no 2 executions process the same repo.

title: Docs only MRs with ~group::global search fail for pipeline config errors
description:
## Challenge

Merge requests with ~"group::global search" run elastic search tests since https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/79949. Docs only MRs with ~"group::global search" will error trying to run jobs like `rspec unit pg12 es8` since the `setup-test-env` job doesn't run for docs MRs.

### Example

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines/531513146

```
'rspec-ee unit pg12 es8 1/14' job needs 'setup-test-env' job, but 'setup-test-env' is not in any previous stage
'rspec-ee unit pg12 es8 1/14' job needs 'retrieve-tests-metadata' job, but 'retrieve-tests-metadata' is not in any previous stage
'rspec-ee unit pg12 es8 1/14' job needs 'compile-test-assets' job, but 'compile-test-assets' is not in any previous stage
'rspec-ee unit pg12 es8 1/14' job needs 'detect-tests' job, but 'detect-tests' is not in any previous stage
'rspec-ee unit pg12 es8 2/14' job needs 'setup-test-env' job, but 'setup-test-env' is not in any previous stage
'rspec-ee unit pg12 es8 2/14' job needs 'retrieve-tests-metadata' job, but 'retrieve-tests-metadata' is not in any previous stage
...
```

title: Add structured events with namespace_id and user_id to 3 CTA PQL experiment
description:
**The problem:** As mentioned in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-data/product-analytics/-/issues/417#note_930833758, tracking for `Upgrade Now` and `Start Trial` CTA were designed in the previous experiment. Hence, we can not distinguish these events for `pql_three_cta_test` experiment - if they were `control` or `candidate`



### Another ***potential*** solution 

could be if we have `Upgrade Now` and `Start Trial` CTA events under `pql_three_cta_test` experiment feature flag (also with the ability to distinguish control and candidate events)


### **Solution:** 

Add `user_id`, `namespace_id` and `plan` to `gitlab_standard` schema for **ALL events in this experiment**. This means that these attributes should be added to the `assignment` event (for `pql_three_cta_test` experiment) as well as for `Upgrade Now` and `Start Trial` CTA events. This will give us the ability to join on `user_id` and `namespace_id` and tie CTA click to control or candidate.

title: Enqueue new container repository twice
description:
## Problem

We would like to speed up the phase 2 registry migration. We have a capacity set at 25, but we don't seem to be hitting that capacity.

![Screen_Shot_2022-05-04_at_1.33.53_PM](/uploads/d2586a742f8b943d0dd4c19614a88d33/Screen_Shot_2022-05-04_at_1.33.53_PM.png)

## Solution

Let's try queuing twice on every import-finalized action! To avoid deduplication we should do a `perform_async` and `perform_in(2.seconds)`.

The 2nd `perform` should live behind a feature flag so we can control this change.

epic.title: Drive the Container Registry migration Phase 2 from Rails

title: Clean redundant code at SubmitService
description:
## Summary

[`ServicePing::SubmitService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/54ac79c6b304545e58da88c7bef65d847b39855a/app/services/service_ping/submit_service.rb) was used to both collect ServicePing payload and sent it to VersionApp (collector endpoint). With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/85503/diffs#a8816b286df493463c0b27197d9813e33eb9e578 collection logic was copied from `SubmitService`, however it original bits remained in place as sort of a fallback mechanism for self managed. Goal of this issue is to clean redundant code from `SubmitService`

## Improvements

<!--

title: Avoid destroy an image repository if a migration is running
description:
## :fire: Problem

Users can destroy image repositories when we are migrating them.

Image repository destruction are delegated to a background job.

If a repository is deleted during its migration, it can lead to inconsistent states.

## :fire_engine: Solution

When the worker starts its execution, check the migration state.

If it's pre importing, pre import done or importing, the execute should re enqueue the job in the future. Use the [dynamic pre-import timeout](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/7374d7c255c19660030bb7119b418b6815e81445/app/workers/container_registry/migration/guard_worker.rb#L84) and a fixed part for the import part.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `async_mr_close_issue`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360639) on production,
that is currently behind the `async_mr_close_issue` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::code review" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_code-review`
- Best individual to reach out to: `@patrickbajao`
- PM: `@phikai`

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Closing of issues via merge request will still work as expected.

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Closing of issues via merge request doesn't work anymore.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

Dashboard to be added.

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

Dashboard to be added.

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=patrickbajao/verification async_mr_close_issue true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab async_mr_close_issue true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com async_mr_close_issue true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360639) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_create_code-review`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue 25 --actors`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue 50 --actors`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue 75 --actors`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue 100 --actors`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360639) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360639) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `async_mr_close_issue`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `async_mr_close_issue` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360639) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete async_mr_close_issue --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete async_mr_close_issue --staging`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete async_mr_close_issue`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set async_mr_close_issue false
```

title: Remove cve from vulnerabilities and remediation in security report schemas
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

`cve` is defined in `definitions/cve` and the description says "Deprecated - use vulnerabilities\[\].id instead", so we want to remove this. However, the same definition is used for `remediation.fixes[].cve`.

`remediation.fixes[].cve` is supposed to reference values provided in `vulnerabilities[].cve` (to map fixes with findings).

So analyzer can use either:

* `vulnerabilities[].cve` and `remediation.fixes[].cve`
* `vulnerabilities[].id` and `remediation.fixes[].id`

If we remove `vulnerabilities[].cve` then it makes sense to remove `remediation.fixes[].cve` at the same time.

This is what we're doing here.

Originally discussed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/339812#note_682576886

title: Labels do not render in Wiki for private projects
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Labels are not rendered correctly in the wiki for private projects.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a private project
2. Create a label
3. Add text to the homepage of the wiki and reference the label
4. View the saved wiki page - the label is not rendered correctly
5. Navigate to the settings and change the project visibility to public
6. View the wiki page - the labels is now rendered correctly

### Example Project

I tested this here: https://gitlab.com/jhyson/sandbox/-/wikis/home. The behaviour is only applicable when I make the project private though.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The label styling is not applied to the `~text` reference in _private_ projects.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Labels referenced in the wiki of a private project render the same way as in the rest of GitLab

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

| Private Project | Public Project |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![CleanShot_2022-05-04_at_10.49.34](/uploads/8a84b6986deb4ff32613c96249b815b6/CleanShot_2022-05-04_at_10.49.34.png) | ![CleanShot_2022-05-04_at_10.50.08](/uploads/75dd7031b1c83799320f5bf0711f0356/CleanShot_2022-05-04_at_10.50.08.png) |

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

title: UX: Fix consistencies in usage quotas tables in narrow/mobile widths
description:
### Problem

The tables in usage quotas aren't consistent in how they react to mobile/narrow screen widths. We should 1) make them consistent and 2) think through information hierarchy to make better, more usable mobile tables.

Also in the storage table, the expanded area and the button that expands it are separated and seems odd.

**Seat usage:**

![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.26.30_PM](/uploads/8146bfe6cd5c5f3d8d4e15b26c914e0b/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.26.30_PM.png)

**Storage:**

| Collapsed | expanded |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.10.15_PM](/uploads/68760c756fbb4c45d9dc17eebb49df2d/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.10.15_PM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.10.23_PM](/uploads/5b877ad90a8870c0bf0a0b36f76a50bd/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.10.23_PM.png) |

Other problems:

The way we collapse tables doesn't take into account the importance of the information. All information is treated equally and given equal vertical real estate, which makes mobile tables really tall. If we were to simply change seat usage to act like storage, each row would take up an entire screen worth of vertical real estate.

Examples around GitLab:

Group members:

| Group members |
| ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.29.17_PM](/uploads/847c89a970d392d687a05160dda2f2b7/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.29.17_PM.png) |

Issues list:

| Regular | Narrow |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.30.49_PM](/uploads/709f92b371fea67ca021b813a9f58f85/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.30.49_PM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.30.58_PM](/uploads/c8ff1c6ba53bfb602b44a0bbce159782/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.30.58_PM.png) |

This is the first example I've seen where some information is hidden on mobile.

Pipelines:

| Regular | Narrow |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.46.21_PM](/uploads/bfa5c304a3f9e00480c90dd5b199934a/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.46.21_PM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.46.38_PM](/uploads/5e219dcbc2233d49a4ff1c938322f06e/Screen_Shot_2022-05-03_at_1.46.38_PM.png) |

Pipelines shows everything, but it does move the "trigger" into the Pipeline field instead of giving it its own field.

### Conclusion:

It seems like the right way to collapse a table is to invert it from columns to rows, like most of the examples. But that doesn't mean we need to show every piece of data. We should think about the data and create priorities for what to show on mobile.

The exploration doesn't answer the question about how to deal with the expand/collapse area being separated.

title: Frontend: Surface the used custom variables for manual jobs and allow to retry the job with updated variables
description:
<!--
## Implementation Issue To-Do list 
(_NOTE: This section can be removed when the issue is ready for creation_)
- [ ] Ensure that issue title is concise yet descriptive
- [ ] Add `Frontend :` or `Backend: ` per group [naming conventions](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/ops/verify/pipeline-authoring/#splitting-issues)
- [ ] Ensure the issue containing the feature or change proposal and related discussions is linked as related to this implementation issue.
- [ ] Aside from default labeling, please make sure to include relevant labels for `type::`, `workflow::`, and `~frontend`/`~backend` labeling.
- [ ] Issues with user-facing changes should include the `~UX` label.
-->

## Summary

Currently, when you run a manual job with additional variables, there's no way to view or update them when you're troubleshooting the job.

## Proposal

Offer the ability to update variables from the job page, and reuse the existing "trigger manual job" page form to surface the used variables.

1. Showing the new link to retry with variables as soon as the user also has the permission to retry the job normally
2. Get the new job data through the current REST call for the variables values.
3. When the user click on the button to retry the job with new variables, take the user to the manual variable page and prefill the fields with the old values (all of them!)
4. Show a Cancel button if the user wishes to return to the job log.

## Implementation Table

title: Issues imported from GitHub do not show up in search results
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Issues imported from GitHub do not show up in search results. In this specific example, the problem is clearly visible when searching for the string "NTP": an issue created in GitHub and migrated doesn't show up in the "All" or "Closed" lists; an issue created in GitLab post-migration DOES show up. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Migrate repository from GitHub.com to GitLab.com via the GitLab API
2. Search for a string present in a closed issue title
3. Fail to find the issue

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Issues migrated from GitHub don't appear in search results, but issues created after migration do appear.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Issues migrated from GitHub appear in search results.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Search result (which should show TWO issues, one Closed and one Open): 

![image](/uploads/45336fcbd9254af5193b8196a73aef47/image.png)

Existing issue in the project that DOES NOT appear in search results:

![image](/uploads/9747b98ea220aa9801355122b4b6bfcc/image.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Create streaming audit event headers
description:
## Overview

Currently, when streaming audit events, GitLab adds a single HTTP header to aid in verification but group owners cannot specify their own HTTP headers.

Certain ingestion services require certain header values for authentication or other purposes.

## Proposal

* Create a new model that represents a HTTP header.
* Create a 1-M association between audit streaming destinations and headers. (This should have a limit per group, 20 perhaps?)
* Create a new GraphQL mutation to create a header for a destination. Something like:

```graphql
mutation {
  externalAuditEventDestinationHeaderCreate(input: { desintationID: "gid://gitlab/somethingsomething/Destination/2, key: "Authorization", value: "Bearer thisisatoken" } ) {
    errors
  }
}
```

* Update the audit streaming worker to include those headers.

epic.title: APIs to specify custom HTTP headers for streaming audit events

title: Clarify required permissions for Gitlab Migration
description:
## Release Notes

GitLab Migration requires **Owner** permissions in order to migrate groups. However, before GitLab 15.1, there was no hint about this required permissions, which created confusions for users without the **Owner** permission, when some groups where not visible for them in the Import page. In this milestone, we added a dismissible notification that tells the user that only groups that the user is the Owner of them are visible. 



We are requiring **Owner** permissions in order to migrate group. This is required because we are using ndjson files as part of import. However, for end user there is no hint about required permissions - I've heard multiple reports from end users confused "why my group is not visible"

<details>
<summary>Original suggestion (outdated)</summary>
I suggest adding dismissible notification about Owner permission

![image](/uploads/ea8cfb91efa923f2a1a87ddae299109b/image.png)

Link "Owner role" should point to [Group member permissions](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html#group-members-permissions) table in docs, where we should add Gitlab migration indicating as available only to group owner 

Please note that second alert about **running outdated version** is not related to this issue and is added only for illustrative purposes how it will look when both alerts are present. For most of scenarios user will only see the blue one

As usual, suggestions for proper text are welcome!
</details>

We will need to change following:
 * pagination text in UI from: `Showing 1-5 of 5 groups that you own from https://gitlab.com`
to: `Showing 1-5 of 5 groups that you own from https://gitlab.com` with added help icon and tooltip with text 

```
What is listed here?
--------------------
Only groups that you have the Owner role for are listed as groups you can import.
```

* empty state text when no groups are present to `You don't have Owner role for any groups in this instance`

`Owner` should link to https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html#group-members-permissions) table in docs, where we should add Gitlab migration indicating as available only to group owner 


### Implementation plan

* All relevant text updates are pretty straightforward and should go to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/import_entities/import_groups/components/import_table.vue
* Relevant docs page is `/user/permissions.md`

title: Backend: Show year in CI minutes usage graph
Migrate Paid tier images with < 6000 tags to the new registry
description:
This issue is for the gradual rollout of existing image repositories in the paid tier to the new registry. Check out the parent epic for more details on this project. https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5523

## Context

This is part of the work to upgrade and migrate the GitLab.com container registry to a new version backed by a metadata database and online garbage collection (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5523). This will be achieved following the gradual migration plan detailed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/container-registry/-/issues/374.

For the gradual [Phase 2](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7423) production rollout, we'll split the work into 5 portions, in this order:

1. **GitLab Org**: We'll start by testing with some custom-made container repositories under `gitlab-org/` and then allow all of its new container repositories to be handled by the metadata DB;
1. **Free Tier**: Following the GitLab Org rollout, we will proceed with a general rollout for the Free tier
1. **Paid tier (with less than 6000 tags)**: After the Free tier, we'll work through a gradual migration of paid customers, excluding major, VIP customers. To start, we'll focus on images with less than 6000 tags.
1. **Paid tier (with more than 6000 tags)**: Since migrating images with more than 6k tags needs to happen over the weekend, we'll attempt to bundle all of these in one or two more weekends.
1. **Major customer** To reduce the risk of impacting users of the GitLab.com container registry that have large amounts of data, a very high activity, or very high availability/stability requirements, we will exclude these from (2) and handle them in this step with a manual gradual rollout, customer by customer.

## Task

Perform general rollout for existing image repositories for the Paid tier for images with less than 6000 tags on GitLab.com. 
- Track progress in the [migration dashboard](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/registry-migration/registry-migration-detail?orgId=1)
- Avoid any customers marked as [VIP](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350933)

title: [SaaS] Add messaging about user overage process to Renewal flow
description:
## Problem to solve

SaaS customers are being surprised and taken off-guard by Quarterly Subscription reconciliations. Because self-service SaaS customers have not historically been charged true-ups, the QSR process and the fact that they have to pay for overages is totally new. See tickets from customers [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/fulfillment-meta/-/issues/337).

## Intended users

**This issue is just for SaaS customers.**

* Group Owners who are **renewing a subscription** through our self-service renewal flow
* See exactly which use cases we're solving for in the [Epic description](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7229#saas-customers).

## Proposal

When a user is **renewing** GitLab, make sure that they are aware of the overage process. Show a message to all customers using the self-service renewal flow that notifies them about the overage process.

[Purchase Design here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/347267/designs/Option_2__Alert_during_checkout_informing_user_of_QSR.png), could we reuse for renewal flow?

Link for `How does billing work?`: `https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/subscriptions/quarterly_reconciliation.html` (shared [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/347267/designs/Option_2__Alert_during_checkout_informing_user_of_QSR.png#note_828638740))

title: Follow-up: Resolve technical debt for Members::ActivationService and Members::AwaitService
description:
With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/86340 we add another parameter to activate members of either a user's memberships, a member (or its user), or all members of the group. Generally the `AwaitService` is also very similar and it makes maybe sense to re-use some code.

**1.  Use Factories**

Maybe we could use a `for_` method, e.g.

```ruby
module Members
  class ActivateService
     def self.for_group(group, current_user)
       members = # find members in group
       new(group, members: members, current_user)
     end

     def self.for_member(group, member, current_user)
       members = # find members in group for member
       new(group, members: members, current_user)
     end

     def self.for_user(group, user, current_user)
       members = # find members in group for user
       new(group, members: members, current_user)
     end
  end
end
```

**2. Re-use code**

There are parts of the code that are identical (e.g. validations), or updating the data, which we might want to re-use.

title: Puma Apdex: slow requests Set PATCH /api/:version/jobs/:id/trace urgency to low
description:
## Summary

Recently, ~"group::pipeline execution" [opted](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/runbooks/-/merge_requests/4561) in to the new SLI durations for endpoints.  This triggered an unhealthy drop in error budget from 99.97% to 99.94% (see below).

![Screen_Shot_2022-05-02_at_12.36.02_PM](/uploads/37f6cc8fa4d4a6d25b7c38337e0d7332/Screen_Shot_2022-05-02_at_12.36.02_PM.png)

Though several endpoints were adjusted in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/85636 to `Low` urgency, `PATCH /api/:version/jobs/:id/trace` was not accounted for.

## Proposal

![Screen_Shot_2022-05-02_at_12.39.55_PM](/uploads/40655d3e3cd8f8533e35fc986d1fe534/Screen_Shot_2022-05-02_at_12.39.55_PM.png)

Set the `urgency` to `Low` for PATCH /api/:version/jobs/:id/trace and observe if this change helps improve the error budget overall for ~"group::pipeline execution".

### Investigation Plan

| **Puma Apdex: slow requests Set PATCH /api/:version/jobs/:id/trace urgency to low** | :point_left: You are here | %"15.0" | ~"workflow::production" |

## Problem to Solve

As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7337 the `Create new merge request` button was changed to follow a new flow. This new flow broke existing instrumentation that tracked the number of unique users who used the button.

## Proposal

title: [License Compliance MR Widget Extension] - Better document loading states
description:
The docs for license compliance are not very clear on the behind the scenes behavior of the Security widgets. In particular there are some behaviors that cause the user to think the feature is broken https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360290

# Possible UI states when a new merge request is newly created

- While the pipeline is in progress, the widgets will continue to show a spinner with a `loading state`
- Once the pipeline is complete, but still parsing the results in the background it will continue showing a `loading state`. This causes the user to think the feature is broken because they have an all green pipeline yet "hanging spinner w/ loading message" In reality we are still parsing the results in the background.
- The final state is pipeline complete, and results parsed state. This is when we show the widget with populated data.


## Possible solutions

- Improve the text copy in the loading state to make things clearer
- Improve the docs to clarify the differences
- Improve the UI by having 3 states. (Loading, Pipeline/Progress in Progress, and Complete)


## Implementation Plan

- Improve the docs to clarify the differences

title: Increase limit size for license management page results.
description:
On the license compliance page we limit results for performance reasons to 100 records. This was done for several reasons at the time.

1. To allow for super fast responsive client side search of license policies
2. To implement a simple client side search functionality and ship quicker

This has caused some problems for some customers where they think the feature is broken if they have over 100 policies defined. For example: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360290

## Temporary Solution

Increase record size to 100

## Implementation Plan

Change `100` to `1000` here:

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/license_compliance/store/actions.js#L69

## Testing

Frontend engineer could add a frontend integration test (shifting left), or SET could add an End to End test that ramps up the number of licenses to 1001, proving out pagination.

title: gemnasium-python fails with error "Keyring is skipped due to an exception"
description:
### Summary

`gemnasium-python` fails to generate a `gl-dependency-scanning-report.json` file and the following error message is displayed in the job logs:

```shell
Keyring is skipped due to an exception: module 'typing' has no attribute '_SpecialForm'
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new project with the following `setup.py`:

   ```py
   from setuptools import setup
   
   setup(
       name = "test project",
       version = "0.0.1",
       install_requires=[
           'keyring==23.3.0',
       ]
   )
   ```

1. Scan the above project with `registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python:2`

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/python-setuptools/-/jobs/2402622659

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

`gemnasium-python` process exits with status 1 and no reports are created.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

`gemnasium-python` process should exit with status 0 and it should create `cyclonedx-*.json` and `gl-dependency-scanning-report.json` files.

### Workaround

Override the `image` field of the `gemnasium-python-dependency_scanning` job to specify the `registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python:2-python-3.9` [image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/python-setuptools/-/blob/ee0d3202b49bdd482019aa30bc4ef8c723b0c463/.gitlab-ci.yml#L12-13):

```yaml
gemnasium-python-dependency_scanning:
  image: registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python:2-python-3.9
```

### Implementation plan

Recently, [v4.2.0 of the typing_extensions library](https://github.com/python/typing/blob/master/typing_extensions/CHANGELOG.md#release-420-april-17-2022) dropped support for Python 3.6, which causes [vrange/python/rangecheck.py](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/blob/c6253e9/vrange/python/rangecheck.py) to fail with the following error if the project being scanned uses `typing_extensions v4.2.0`:

> `Keyring is skipped due to an exception: module 'typing' has no attribute '_SpecialForm'`

We can fix this by adding a constraint to the `typing_extensions` package to ensure that `v4.2.0` is _not installed_, and a version that supports `Python 3.6` is installed instead.

1. Update [requirements.txt](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/blob/4b7ad0b/requirements.txt#L20-20) to add a constraint to the `typing_extensions` package:

   ```shell
   typing_extensions>4.1,<4.2
   ```

1. Add an [image integration test case](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/blob/4b7ad0b/spec/image_spec.rb#L286-307) to show that this bug has been fixed.

/cc @thiagocsf @fcatteau @gonzoyumo @sam.white

description:
We should include a guide for investigating error budget issues in our handbook, so that we will not need to repeat the work that has already been done.

The instructions that should be included in the guide can be found in [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/product-intelligence/-/issues/548#note_904580323). The guide should include links to the Grafana views and the Kibana view, with a short description of steps to take when investigating apdex issues.

#### Extra information

Let's make sure we include the information that error budget is only counted based on the % of failing requests. "How much" do the requests exceed the met expectations does not matter for the error budget: for example, if we had an endpoint with a set goal of 1s request duration, then bringing the request duration from 10s to 5s would not introduce any improvements to the error budget.

In the Grafana dashboard, the blocks that specify error budget in seconds/minutes are only based on an estimation.

epic.title: Product Intelligence error budget improvements

title: Reduce volume of diff view event calls
description: Currently, we hit the `/api/:version/usage_data/increment_unique_users` API with 5.5 million events for every of the 4 pairs view settings per week. This can be seen in [Kibana](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/8ebccdd0-ca08-11ec-b73f-692cc1ae8214), by investigating the `json.params.value` value: Probably, we fire events every time someone views a diff and we shouldn't have to do that. We could improve our error budget by reducing the volume of diff view event calls, perhaps by caching or rethinking how and when the events are fired.

epic.title: Product Intelligence error budget improvements

title: Investigate decline of `/increment_unique_users` endpoint apdex
description:
The `/api/:version/usage_data/increment_unique_users` endpoint experienced a sharp increase in `apdex` violations on `March 31 - April 1 2022`. This can be observed when setting appropriate daterange on the error budget [Grafana board](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-detail-product_intelligence/stage-groups-product-intelligence-group-error-budget-detail?orgId=1).
The problem has already been discussed in [another issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/product-intelligence/-/issues/548#note_904580323), but the reason of the decline has not been found.

The outcome of this issue should be a creation of another issue, targeted towards fixing the root cause of this performance decline.

title: Page load performance issues when CODEOWNERS contains a large amount of members
description:
### Summary

Too many members from the CODEOWNERS file are displayed on file content pages which results in extremely long loading times.

This is for a repository where the intended workflow is to let anyone approve the creation of new files, but the modification of existing files is subject to approval. Since the approval is set to follow code owners, everyone needs to be added as a global rule to allow

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a CODEOWNERS file that references a group containing a lot of users (100-1000+) for all files in the repo
```
* @everyone
* some/specific/file @someone @someone-else
```
2. Try to load the content of any repo file covered by the first default rule in the browser.

### Example Project

No access to a group with a large amount of users to test on public gitlab.com

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Browsing pages for files and folders becomes extremely slow and difficult as thousands of users are displayed above file and folder content

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Only some amount of users would be displayed to reduce the load times and impact on the page usability

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
![codeowners](/uploads/871a3bc0c8ed93cf4201e904b017c394/codeowners.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on a internally-hosted version of Gitlab EE

### Proposal

Place a "show all" button to expand to the full list on-demand. See [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/361004#note_1092864377) for UX mockup.

* show 5 names maximum and afterwards we would show a tertiary button that says `# more` (where # = total count of members - 5 visible members).
* When expanded the button label says "show less" to collapse the list back to 5 visible members.

title: Frontend: Dialog to present to maintainers to take ownership of pipeline schedule
description:
### Problem

As a result of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/118782, currently, we don't allow the ability for maintainers that currently don't have ownership of the pipeline schedule to view or edit it at all.

### Proposal

When users attempt to edit the pipeline schedule by clicking on the :pencil2: icon, they will be presented with a dialog similar to below:

```
(Title)Take ownership 

Only the owner of a pipeline schedule can make changes to it. Do you want to take ownership of this schedule?


<Cancel> <Take ownership>
```

If the user chooses `Cancel` on the dialog, they will be still able to view the edit page but could not make any changes to it.

title: [Frontend] Allow "all protected branches" for MR approval rules in projects
description:
[[_TOC_]]

### Problem to solve 

<!-- What is the user problem you are trying to solve with this issue? -->

Users want to ensure proper separation of duties using merge request approvers in their projects for specific branches. Today they do this by manually entering approval settings for individual branches. This is very time consuming and error-prone, especially if a project has dozens of protected branches or when the protected branches changes.

### Proposal 

<!-- Use this section to explain the feature and how it will work. It can be helpful to add technical details, design proposals, and links to related epics or issues. -->

Allow users to define an approval rule they would like to use for all protected branches in a project. Add a new option, `All protected branches`, to merge request approval rules at the _project level_. 

While also replacing `Any eligible user` → `All eligible users` and `Any branch` → `All branches` to keep consistent ~"UI text" 

Automatically apply this approval setting to any branches that become protected, even if they were not originally.

#### Scenario illustration

A merge request approval rule "Villains" targets `All protected branches`

![Branch_update](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/45652423dedd312aa9d51324b7cadd03/Branch_update.png)

[Open Figma →](https://www.figma.com/file/0ryR4kblICZYQYDfXAcAo6/%F0%9F%94%92-18488-Blunt-Hammer?node-id=1839%3A23497)

### Implementation Plan

~frontend - :three: 

1. Update the UI text for **all** instances of `Any eligible user` and `Any branch` as they are used by the same components across the product
    1. Double-check the documentation for the areas using these UI components to see if screenshots/descriptions need updating too
    1. `Any branch` rename was done in !70552+
1. Add a new selectable option in the branches dropdown for all protected branches **only** for projects level
1. Update the forms store to handle the new option and submit it to the ~backend correctly for saving
1. Update the approval rule list to show all protected branches
1. Update/add specs

### Further details 

Background evidence around the problem space
- https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4367#note_619317599
- https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4367#note_620116744

### Out of scope
**Group and subgroup implementation**
- This proposal will set the foundation to create a useful generic rule that could be scaled to the group level in the future.
- Future issues/epics will cover group and subgroup

title: Turn on masking of new access token and remove reliance on `created-access-token` class
description:
Part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/357848.

## Aim

* [x] Set the masking on for new tokens (as default) and modify the QA end-to-end test to toggle the visibility of the new tokens.

* [x]  In addition, we want to rely on the new selector `data-qa-selector="created_access_token_field"` instead of the older `created-access-token-field` class. Accomplished by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/94401+

## Background

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/84373, we were unable to turn on the masking of new access token without modifying the QA end-to-end tests. Hence, we decided to initially show the token unmasked and later, on a follow up MR, turn the masking on.

title: ConsistencyWorker exceeds 300 seconds
description:
### Problem

`Analytics::CycleAnalytics::ConsistencyWorker` is exceeding 300 seconds and takes the most out of our error budget.



### Proposal

https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7839#note_900630602

In the consistency worker, we limit the maximum runtime to 5 minutes however, we do the check after one "item" (group) is finished processing. The processing of one item can be longer than 5 minutes.

1. Iterate each aggregated issues and MRs
1. If the issue or MR is already deleted, remove the aggregated row.

For large groups, this will take some time. We can fix it by tracking the execution. When the 5-minute limit is done, we stop the processing. The next job would continue the processing where the previous job finished.

title: [Spike] Update cloud license validation logic
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Proposal

Investigate the validation logic we currently have for Cloud License around true-ups.

Ideally, we can loosen that validation logic given that we may not use true-ups, however, we may need to check that's the case if the instance never syncs.

If we default to true-ups when the instance stops syncing (so not enough data) we may want to add a validation such as "Validate true-ups after month 3 if there was no syncing done in the last 3 months"

This is assuming that we issue a license that expires for a year when Cloud License and Reconciliations are both `true`. Another solution (more restrictive) here would be to expire the license in 3 months.

#### Current Logic
Briefly, the [current](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e3a60158483fef94181b9156cc0b08f07eaebad6/VERSION) trueup logic for both cloud and legacy will:

* Check/validate trueups only [if all 3 of](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e3a60158483fef94181b9156cc0b08f07eaebad6/ee/app/models/license.rb#L245-249) `trueup_quantity`, `trueup_from`, `trueup_to` are present in the license, and `reconciliation_completed` is empty/nil
  * `trueup_quantity` comes [directly from subscription data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/customers-gitlab-com/-/blob/06c6a6279401591bf8621fd791d735cbd4a6572d/app/models/license.rb#L98) if it exists
  * A positive integer value of `trueup_quantity` [results in both](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/customers-gitlab-com/-/blob/06c6a6279401591bf8621fd791d735cbd4a6572d/app/models/license.rb#L152-157) `trueup_from` / `_to` also being set (not necessarily vice versa tho)
  * `reconciliation_completed` comes from [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/customers-gitlab-com/-/blob/06c6a6279401591bf8621fd791d735cbd4a6572d/app/models/license.rb#L106), pretty sure is only set after a QSR happens
* Fail if not enough trueups (within 10% threshold), otherwise:
* [Proceed to check if](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e3a60158483fef94181b9156cc0b08f07eaebad6/ee/app/models/license.rb#L489-490) `:active_user_count` in license [is greater than or equal to ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e3a60158483fef94181b9156cc0b08f07eaebad6/ee/app/models/license.rb#L504-508)`daily_billable_users_count` (within 10% threshold), fail if not
  * This step [also happens](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e3a60158483fef94181b9156cc0b08f07eaebad6/ee/app/models/license.rb#L37) when no trueups are present, but a QSR has taken place
* Accept the license

related:

* `daily_billable_users_count` is a bit contrived, but is effectively the value of `User.billable.count` as recorded once per day [around 23:50 server time](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/config/initializers/1_settings.rb#L585), and therefore is somewhat susceptible to race conditions
* The related user-checking logic, `check_users_limit`, is [never run when a license has trueup checking to do](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e3a60158483fef94181b9156cc0b08f07eaebad6/ee/app/models/license.rb#L35), and also [is never run at all for cloud licenses](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e3a60158483fef94181b9156cc0b08f07eaebad6/ee/app/models/license.rb#L459-460)

title: Bulk propagating integrations sets the created_at and updated_at timestamps
description:
We currently set the `created_at` and `updated_at` timestamps of project-level integrations to the instance-level timestamps when we propagate changes to them. This also affects the data field tables. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/355610#note_929543539.

Our database schema for `integrations` also allows null timestamps.

### Proposal

We should:

- When bulk creating, set `created_at` and `updated_at` to current time.
- When bulk updating, set only the `updated_at` to current time (and not change the existing `created_at` value).
- Migrate a not null constraint for `created_at` and `updated_at` columns of `integrations`.

title: Remove RepositoryPushAuditEventWorker
description:
#### Description

We've made `RepositoryPushAuditEventWorker` a no-op sidekiq worker in %15.0 via https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/86131 so that any queued jobs in redis for this worker could be drained. We missed doing this in the initial MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/85521 to remove this worker. As part of this issue we need to completely remove this worker from the codebase.

### Implementation Plan

Remove all occurrences of `RepositoryPushAuditEventWorker` basically a revert of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/86131.

title: Investigate a WASM or client-based approach to remote development environments
description:
## Purpose

Investigate whether a purely browser-based solution can exist for Remote Development. Web Assembly (WASM) is maturing and may provide an opportunity to solve the remote development needs for at least some of our customers, particularly those working on JavaScript applications. 

## Scope

The completion of this issue should be an assessment of WASM as a front-end option for remote development. Answering the questions: 

1. Can we meet our customers' expectations with a purely browser-based solution? 
2. What functionality can be achieved using WASM today? 
3. What functionality can we imagine being available in the next 12-24 months? 
4. What features are never going to be possible with a browser-based solution? 

## Details

One of the big hurdles to rolling out a remote development offering is the amount of infrastructure required to provision and manage containers. What if we ran everything locally in the browser? 

Others are paving the way in this area. [Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/) and [Replit](https://replit.com/) are two worth investigating. In particular, digging into Stackblitz's [open source projects](https://github.com/stackblitz) and [this blog post](https://intuitiveexplanations.com/tech/replit/) about an open source implementation of Replit's browser-based runtime could help us understand if there is anything we can do in this space. See also [runwasm](https://www.runwasm.com/)

## Outcome

There are aspects of a WASM runtime that are extremely compelling. Stackblitz, among others, have been pushing the boundaries here and the future is very exciting. There are, however, significant limitations when compared to a server-based runtime environment. Specifically: 

- Browser runtimes are limited in the languages they can support
- Complex, multi-project environments could be a very difficult challenge
- It's only supported on Chrome and bleeding-edge browsers, though adoption is picking up speed

There are many benefits to weigh against those limitations, but for our customers and their complex environments, it will remain a long-term play and not something we look to implement in the near future.

epic.title: Remote Development Direction 2: Browser runtime

* [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary. If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1), the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
  * [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
* [x] Close [the feature issue](/gitlab-org/gitlab/master/ISSUE%20LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
* [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
  * [x] `/chatops run feature delete calendly_invite_link --dev`
  * [x] `/chatops run feature delete calendly_invite_link --staging`
  * [x] `/chatops run feature delete calendly_invite_link`
* [x] Update and close the rollout issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330340
* [x] Inform @jackib (to remove the Calendly account).

title: Rollout `dast_ui_redesign` feature flag
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [this feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/355640), that is currently
behind feature flag `dast_ui_redesign`

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Secure:Dynamic Analysis
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_secure-dynamic-analysis`
- Best individual to reach out to: Artur Fedorov, Dheeraj Joshi
- PM: Seth Berger

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab-foss <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [x] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Prevent editing approval rules not enforced on project level
description:
### Summary The instance level setting `Prevent editing approval rules in projects and merge requests` greys out the `Approvals required` approval rule attribute, but does not prevent editing of approval rules via the API. A simple CSS edit of the page enables a `Maintainer` to still change `Approvals required`. The group level setting `Prevent editing approval rules in projects and merge requests` does not grey out the `Approvals required` approval rule attribute and does not seem to have any effect at all. ### Steps to reproduce * Configure `Prevent editing approval rules in projects and merge requests` on the instance * Open a project as a `Maintainer` * Access the Merge Request approval rule settings * Right click the `Approvals required` field and enable it via CSS * Change `Approvals required`. The change is sent to the API and performed * Using the group level setting, there does not seem to be any effect at all and settings can be edited freely on project level ### Example video ![Changing_MR_approvals_not_prevented](/uploads/519515ffb5380b0e6ef243da2a0989d1/Changing_MR_approvals_not_prevented.mp4) ### What is the current *bug* behavior? `Prevent editing approval rules in projects and merge requests` does not prevent editing approval rules in projects. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? `Prevent editing approval rules in projects and merge requests` prevents editing approval rules in projects. ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info

title: Display verification token on streaming audit event destination screen
description: ### Release notes ### Problem to solve Users today use the `verificationToken` value in our [API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/audit_event_streaming.html#use-the-api) to confirm that the audit events being sent from GitLab are valid and not from an alternate source impersonating GitLab. However, this value is only available through the API. If a user wants to use the UI, they can't see this token and must rely on the API. This introduces an extra step and reduces the value of the UI. ### Proposal Add the verification token to the streaming audit events UI. ### Design __Attached designs are the end-vision, the below design is for this issue__ ![image](/uploads/896aa3d687545628bc4adb64d5dc965a/image.png) ### Implementation plan ~frontend - :two: * Add `verificationToken` to [retrieval GraphQL query](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/audit_events/graphql/get_external_destinations.query.graphql) * Add a `` block with the verification token and tooltip to the [stream item](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/f46f5c156a848fa2a308bbee884b318a44a72700/ee/app/assets/javascripts/audit_events/components/stream/stream_item.vue#L72) * Make sure the code block has a tab index for keyboard users * Update specs * Update https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/audit_event_streaming.html#verify-event-authenticity to note that you can find the `verificationToken` via the UI ### Intended users * [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager) *This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
